channel.title: NPR Programs: All Things Considered
channel.description: All Things Considered hosts Ailsa Chang, Mary Louise Kelly, Juana Summers and Scott Detrow present the program's trademark mix of news, interviews, commentaries, reviews, and offbeat features 7 days a week.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: Netanyahu makes a high-stakes bid to end his corruption trial
item.description: Israeli PM Netanyahu seeks to end his corruption trial through a presidential pardon while facing new political and public pressure.
item.content:encoded: Israeli PM Netanyahu seeks to end his corruption trial through a presidential pardon while facing new political and public pressure.
item.dc:creator: Miles Parks

item.title: Congress steps in as questions mount over who authorized a second strike at sea
item.description: Congress is investigating reports that Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth ordered a second strike on survivors of a drug-boat attack, putting the legality of the recent U.S. military campaign under scrutiny.
item.content:encoded: Congress is investigating reports that Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth ordered a second strike on survivors of a drug-boat attack, putting the legality of the recent U.S. military campaign under scrutiny.
item.dc:creator: Miles Parks

item.title: Closed-door MAHA summit offers a glimpse into the administration's evolving health priorities
item.description: Dr. Sandro Galea, a distinguished professor in public health and dean of the Washington University School of Public Health, warns that the administration's turn toward alternative medicine risks sidelining science in federal health policy.
item.content:encoded: Dr. Sandro Galea, a distinguished professor in public health and dean of the Washington University School of Public Health, warns that the administration's turn toward alternative medicine risks sidelining science in federal health policy.
item.dc:creator: Ahmad Damen

item.title: Tasmania takes a historic step to repair harm from its past anti-gay laws
item.description: Tasmania is launching Australia's first compensation program for men once criminalized under anti-gay laws, raising difficult questions about how to measure and remedy decades of harm.
item.content:encoded: Tasmania is launching Australia's first compensation program for men once criminalized under anti-gay laws, raising difficult questions about how to measure and remedy decades of harm.
item.dc:creator: Kristina Kukolja

item.title: The Brazilian moms fighting for their children ten years after Zika
item.description: When the Zika crisis hit Brazil, women infected with the virus gave birth to babies with a debilitating condition. Some of the moms joined together to build a new life and to push for reparations.
item.content:encoded: When the Zika crisis hit Brazil, women infected with the virus gave birth to babies with a debilitating condition. Some of the moms joined together to build a new life and to push for reparations.
item.dc:creator: Ari Daniel

item.title: Why some movies grow stale
item.description: NPR's Marc Rivers and Mallory Yu revisit the movies that haven't aged well and explore why they fall apart on rewatch.
item.content:encoded: NPR's Marc Rivers and Mallory Yu revisit the movies that haven't aged well and explore why they fall apart on rewatch.
item.dc:creator: Marc Rivers

item.title: In a new novel, a dream house becomes an obsession
item.description: In her debut novel, Marisa Kashino tells the story of a woman who goes to extreme lengths to secure her dream home, and becomes a nightmare to everyone around her.
item.content:encoded: In her debut novel, Marisa Kashino tells the story of a woman who goes to extreme lengths to secure her dream home, and becomes a nightmare to everyone around her.
item.dc:creator: Miles Parks

item.title: How one attack is reshaping the fight over immigration policy
item.description: The aftermath of the D.C. attack has brought tightened security and new immigration limits from the Trump administration.
item.content:encoded: The aftermath of the D.C. attack has brought tightened security and new immigration limits from the Trump administration.
item.dc:creator: Miles Parks

item.title: West Virginia's governor on what the D.C. shooting means for his state
item.description: West Virginia Governor Patrick Morrisey discusses the D.C. shooting that targeted two Guard members from his state.
item.content:encoded: West Virginia Governor Patrick Morrisey discusses the D.C. shooting that targeted two Guard members from his state.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Robbins

item.title: A Palestinian-American teen freed from Israeli prison comes home needing urgent care
item.description: For Mohammed Ibrahim's family, this Thanksgiving was the moment they had been waiting for.
item.content:encoded: For Mohammed Ibrahim's family, this Thanksgiving was the moment they had been waiting for.
item.dc:creator: Kat Lonsdorf
